questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with moderate persistent asthma presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath, wheezing and chest tightness. He is unable to provide much history due to confusion and lethargy. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0 °F), heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 32/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On examination, the patient is in distress and using accessory muscles for breathing. On auscultation there is bilateral expiratory wheezing and a prolonged expiratory phase. Arterial blood gas analysis is provided below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Test
Result
pH
7.28
PaO2
45 mm Hg
PaCO2
62 mm Hg
HCO3-
24 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a severe exacerbation of asthma and an arterial blood gas (ABG) demonstrating acute, uncompensated respiratory acidosis (low pH, high PaCO2, normal HCO3-) and hypoxemia. Given his respiratory distress and inadequate ventilation (high PaCO2), mechanical ventilation is necessary to stabilize his breathing and manage the acid-base disturbance.

ABG is a useful tool in assessing and managing patients with respiratory compromise. In addition to providing insight into a patient’s oxygenation status, it allows clinicians to determine their acid-base balance and whether disturbances are related to ventilation efficiency. When interpreting an ABG the key components are pH, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), bicarbonate (HCO3-), and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2).  In respiratory acidosis, the ABG typically reveals a decreased pH (< 7.35) and elevated PaCO2 (> 45 mmHg). In addition, the HCO3- may be relatively normal if the acidosis is uncompensated or acute, or it may be elevated when there is metabolic compensation.

The management of respiratory acidosis depends on the underlying etiology and severity. In cases of respiratory distress, the goal is to improve ventilation so that excess CO2 can be eliminated. This typically includes managing the underlying pathology and respiratory support. Noninvasive ventilation (e.g. BiPAP) or invasive mechanical ventilation are options depending on the severity of respiratory failure, mental status, hemodynamic status, and concurrent conditions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhaled fluticasone:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with a severe asthma exacerbation resulting in acute respiratory acidosis. While glucocorticoids (typically systemic, rather than inhaled) are used in the management of asthma exacerbations, stabilization of his respiratory status takes priority at this point in time.  
❌ High-flow oxygen via nasal cannula:
Incorrect: While oxygen therapy is crucial in asthma exacerbations, high-flow oxygen alone is insufficient in this patient with altered mental status and severe respiratory acidosis as it will not provide the necessary assisted ventilation.  
❌ Nebulized albuterol:
Incorrect: This is a standard treatment for asthma exacerbations, but given the severity of the patient's presentation, stabilization of his respiratory status with mechanical ventilation is most important at this point in time.  
❌ Intravenous magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Intravenous magnesium sulfate can be used in severe asthma exacerbations, but it is less critical than securing the airway and providing mechanical ventilation in a patient like this one with respiratory failure.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with interstitial lung disease is admitted to the intensive care unit for severe pneumonia. On admission, the patient is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. On the second day of hospitalization, the patient appears restless and diaphoretic. Temperature is 38.3 °C (101.0 °F), heart rate is 108/min, respiratory rate is set on the ventilator, blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on FiO2 of 60%. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds and bilateral crackles in the lower lung fields. A morning arterial blood gas analysis is shown below. Which of the following ventilator settings is most likely contributing to the patient’s laboratory findings?

Test
Result
pH
7.50
PaCO2
28 mm Hg
HCO3-
22 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient on mechanical ventilation has an arterial blood gas (ABG) with high pH and low PaCO2, which together are indicative of respiratory alkalosis. Of the answer choices listed, a high respiratory rate set on the ventilator is the most likely contributor to the patient's acute respiratory alkalosis, as it directly facilitates increased CO2 exhalation.

ABG analysis is a crucial tool for monitoring patients on mechanical ventilation as it provides vital information about the patient's respiratory status including oxygenation, ventilation and acid-base balance. The ABG measures several key parameters of acid-base status: pH, which indicates the acidity or alkalinity of the blood; partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), reflecting the respiratory component; and bicarbonate (HCO3-), representing the metabolic component. In cases of respiratory alkalosis, the ABG typically shows an elevated pH (> 7.45 and a reduced PaCO2 (< 35 mmHg), indicating excessive loss of carbon dioxide.

Respiratory alkalosis can be caused by various factors in a patient on a ventilator, most notably a high respiratory rate or high tidal volume, both of which lead to increased minute ventilation and thus exhalation of CO2. Decreasing the respiratory rate and/or tidal volume is essential to prevent and correct respiratory alkalosis, ensuring the patient's pH remains within a normal range for optimal cardiopulmonary functioning.  

Option Analysis

✅ High respiratory rate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Low tidal volume:
Incorrect: While tidal volume is one of the two major components of minute ventilation (and thus PaCO2 levels), a low tidal volume would most likely result in respiratory acidosis (excess PaCO2), not alkalosis.  
❌ High positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP):
Incorrect: PEEP is used to keep the alveoli open and improve oxygenation. It doesn’t typically cause respiratory alkalosis.  
❌ High fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2)  :
Incorrect: A high FiO2 setting increases the amount of oxygen delivered to the patient and is used to correct hypoxemia. It does not cause respiratory alkalosis.  
❌ Low inspiratory flow rate:
Incorrect: A low inspiratory flow rate can prolong the duration of inspiration, potentially leading to discomfort and asynchrony with the ventilator. It does not usually cause respiratory alkalosis directly.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of vomiting and diarrhea. Her medical history is significant for hypertension which is typically well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. She reports no fever, chest pain or difficulty breathing. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 108/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination the patient has dry mucous membranes and diminished skin turgor. Laboratory studies are shown below. Based on these studies, what is the significance of this patient’s PaCO2 value?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with laboratory studies indicating metabolic alkalosis (elevated pH and bicarbonate), likely resulting from gastrointestinal losses and diuretic use. The elevated PaCO2 in the context of this metabolic alkalosis suggests a compensatory increase in carbon dioxide retention by the lungs to balance the pH (respiratory compensation).

To assess the acid-base status, an arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis provides critical information about the patient's pH, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. The pH indicates the overall acid-base balance, with normal values ranging from 7.35 to 7.45. PaCO2, typically ranging from 35 to 45 mmHg, reflects the respiratory component, as it is directly influenced by ventilation. Bicarbonate, with normal values between 22 and 26 mEq/L, represents the metabolic component as it is regulated by the kidneys. Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an elevated pH (> 7.45) and bicarbonate level (> 26 mEq/L). This condition can result from excessive loss of gastric acid (through vomiting or gastric suction) or an accumulation of bicarbonate (due to factors like excessive bicarbonate intake or potassium depletion).

Compensation in acid-base disorders refers to the physiologic responses that attempt to restore normal pH. There are two types of compensation: respiratory and metabolic. Respiratory compensation, driven by changes in ventilation, responds to metabolic disturbances. When metabolic alkalosis occurs, the body may retain CO2 to increase PaCO2 and help counteract the elevated pH. Conversely, metabolic compensation occurs in response to primary respiratory disorders. The kidneys either increase or decrease bicarbonate reabsorption and secretion to counteract changes in blood CO2 levels. These compensatory mechanisms, however, do not completely correct the pH but help to minimize the severity of the pH imbalance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Respiratory compensation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metabolic compensation:
Incorrect: The PaCO2 on ABG assesses the respiratory component, not the metabolic component, of a patient’s acid-base status.  
❌ Inadequate respiratory effort:
Incorrect: Inadequate respiratory effort would lead to hypoventilation and result in respiratory acidosis, not the alkalosis observed in this patient's ABG results.  
❌ Renal compensation:
Incorrect: Renal compensation would be a response to a primary respiratory disorder, which is not indicated in this scenario. This patient’s hydrochlorothiazide use, vomiting and diarrhea, and ABG findings indicate the primary issue here is metabolic, not respiratory.  
❌ No respiratory or metabolic compensation:
Incorrect: The elevated PaCO2, bicarbonate and pH together indicate a compensatory respiratory response to the primary metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 1-week history of excessive thirst and urination. He reports having to wake up several times at night to drink water and urinate, which has significantly disturbed his sleep. His past medical history includes bipolar disorder and hypertension, which are managed with lithium and hydrochlorothiazide, respectively. Additionally, he underwent a transsphenoidal resection of a pituitary adenoma recently. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests are detailed below. Which of the following is the biggest risk factor in this patient for the likely underlying diagnosis?

 Laboratory study  Result 
 Serum sodium  147 mEq/L 
 Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg 
 Urine osmolality (baseline)  250 mOsm/kg 
 Urine osmolality (after desmopressin challenge)  400 mOsm/kg

choices.text: Recent transsphenoidal resection of a pituitary adenoma

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of polydipsia, polyuria, and nocturia, and laboratory evidence of plasma hyperosmolality, hypernatremia, and urine hypoosmolality are consistent with diabetes insipidus (DI). Additionally, the >50% elevation in urine osmolality after the desmopressin challenge suggests central DI as the underlying diagnosis. From the history provided, the recent transsphenoidal resection of a pituitary adenoma would be the most likely etiology.  

DI is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia due to impaired water reabsorption in the renal tubules leading to excessive dilute urine. The condition can be classified into two main types: central (neurogenic) DI and nephrogenic DI. Central DI arises from a deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion from the posterior pituitary. Etiologies include injuries or conditions affecting the hypothalamus or pituitary gland, such as trauma, neurosurgical procedures, tumors, infiltrative diseases, or genetic disorders. Nephrogenic DI occurs when the kidneys are unable to respond properly to ADH. This condition can be inherited or acquired, with common causes including chronic kidney disease, certain medications (like lithium), and electrolyte imbalances.    

Distinguishing between central and nephrogenic DI is typically achieved through water deprivation tests and/or ADH analog (desmopressin) administration. In central DI administering desmopressin will reduce urine output and increase urine osmolality because the kidneys can respond to this synthetic hormone. In nephrogenic DI there will be little to no response to the desmopressin challenge, as the problem lies in the kidneys' ability to respond to ADH rather than in the production of ADH itself.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recent transsphenoidal resection of a pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lithium use:
Incorrect: While lithium can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by affecting the kidney's ability to respond to antidiuretic hormone, the significant increase in the patient’s urine osmolality after the desmopressin challenge points toward a central cause.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide use:
Incorrect: Hydrochlorothiazide can lead to alterations in urine volume and electrolyte imbalances, but it does not typically cause the pattern of findings found in diabetes insipidus. The significant response to desmopressin indicates a central rather than nephrogenic cause.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Although the incidence of various diseases changes with age, there is no direct link suggesting that the patient's age is a risk factor for developing central diabetes insipidus.
❌ Bipolar disorder:
Incorrect: Bipolar disorder itself does not predispose to diabetes insipidus. The treatment for bipolar disorder, such as lithium, can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus; however, the increase in osmolality after the desmopressin challenge points toward a central cause.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a cough and shortness of breath for the past two days. The patient has not had any recent respiratory infections, has no past significant medical history, and does not take any medication. The cough is productive of yellow sputum and has worsened over the past two days. Temperature is 38.2 ºC (100.8 ºF), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 158/95 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 95% on room air. On physical examination, there are biapical wheezes on pulmonary auscultation, which the patient states are chronic. There is no digital clubbing and no new skin lesions. Chest radiograph shows mild left lingular pneumonia. Serum and urine laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s metabolic alkalosis? 

 Laboratory Study     Result    
 Serum Sodium     144 mEq/L    
 Serum Potassium     3.0 mEq/L    
 Serum Bicarbonate     30 mEq/L    
 Blood urea nitrogen     16 mg/dL    
 Serum creatinine     1.0 mg/dL    
 Urine osmolality     400 mOsm/kg     
 Urine chloride     45 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with community-acquired pneumonia and is incidentally found to have metabolic alkalosis associated with hypertension and hypokalemia. These findings, along with an elevated urine chloride, suggest hyperaldosteronism.   

For patients with metabolic alkalosis, the history and physical can help narrow down the differential diagnosis and guide further evaluation. Urine chloride can often help differentiate between common etiologies, particularly if the cause is unknown or multiple potential contributors are present. A low urine chloride (≤ 20 mEq/L), also called chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis, indicates gastrointestinal loss (nasogastric tube suctioning or laxative abuse) or cystic fibrosis.    

A normal/high urine chloride (> 20 mEq/L), also called chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis, indicates disorders of the kidneys or the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. A normal blood pressure will usually point toward excessive diuretic use or Bartter or Gitelman syndrome.    

Patients with hypertension have excess activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. A serum renin level should be checked next. If serum renin is high, then abdominal imaging should be performed to look for a renin-secreting tumor, while a renal Doppler ultrasound can be done to look for renal artery stenosis. If plasma renin is low, then aldosterone should be checked, and patients should be evaluated for primary hyperaldosteronism or Cushing syndrome, depending upon aldosterone levels and additional studies.   

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperaldosteronism:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chronic vomiting:
Incorrect: While chronic vomiting (or nasogastric tube suctioning) can lead to metabolic alkalosis, this would lead to a low urine chloride (≤ 20 mEq/L). This patient’s history and labs do not support this. 
❌ Chronic diarrhea:
Incorrect: While chronic diarrhea (especially from laxative abuse) can lead to metabolic alkalosis, this would lead to a low urine chloride (≤ 20 mEq/L). This patient’s history and labs do not support this. 
❌ Cystic fibrosis:
Incorrect: While this patient does have chronic wheezing, the patient has no clubbing, recurrent respiratory infections, or other associated symptoms. In addition, cystic fibrosis may cause metabolic alkalosis with a low urine chloride (≤ 20 mEq/L). 
❌ Bartter syndrome:
Incorrect: This patient is hypertensive and has no polyuria, abdominal cramps, or family history suggestive of Bartter syndrome. Patients with Bartter and Gitelman syndrome will have normal blood pressure and associated symptoms.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of progressively worsening headaches, dizziness, and increasing confusion. Her family reports that she had complained of visual disturbances, including blurred vision, and seeing flashing lights. Her medical history is significant for hypertension, and she has been non-compliant with her medications. On arrival, her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 82 beats/minute, blood pressure is 200/112 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 28/minute, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On examination, she appears disoriented and has difficulty following commands. Neurological examination reveals bilateral papilledema and a positive Babinski sign bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are listed below. Which of the following additional tests should be performed next? 

 Laboratory Test     Result   
 WBC     7,500 /µL    
 Hemoglobin     13.5 g/dL    
 Platelets     250,000 /µL    
 Sodium     138 mEq/L    
 Potassium     4.1 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     20 mEq/L    
 Calcium     9.2 mg/dL    
 pH     7.48    
 PaCO2     32 mm Hg    
 PaO2     98 mm Hg

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine

questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of progressively worsening headaches, visual disturbances, confusion, and the presence of bilateral papilledema suggest increased intracranial pressure. These findings, along with ABG results showing respiratory alkalosis, point toward a possible intracranial pathology, such as a mass lesion or hemorrhage, as the cause of central neurogenic hyperventilation. A CT scan of the head should be performed next to identify intracranial abnormalities.

Respiratory alkalosis is a condition characterized by a decrease in arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO2 < 35 mm Hg) due to excessive alveolar ventilation, leading to an increase in blood pH (> 7.45). Bicarbonate levels may be normal or slightly decreased as a compensatory mechanism. Intracranial pathologies, such as a mass lesion, hemorrhage, or other conditions resulting in increased intracranial pressure, can lead to respiratory alkalosis through central neurogenic hyperventilation. The brainstem's respiratory centers are sensitive to changes in intracranial pressure and can become overstimulated, causing an increase in the respiratory rate and subsequent hyperventilation.

When respiratory alkalosis is suspected in the context of neurological symptoms, immediate steps should include imaging studies, such as a CT scan of the head to identify the underlying pathology. It is crucial to stabilize the patient's condition, which may involve measures to reduce intracranial pressure, such as elevating the head of the bed, administering hypertonic saline or mannitol, and ensuring adequate oxygenation and ventilation. Consulting neurology or neurosurgery specialists is essential for further evaluation and intervention, which might include surgical decompression or other targeted therapies depending on the underlying cause.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography (CT) of the head :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Echocardiogram :
Incorrect: An echocardiogram would be appropriate if there were concerns about cardiac function or heart failure. However, in this case, the patient’s primary symptoms and physical findings are more suggestive of a neurological issue rather than a cardiac problem. 
❌ Chest radiograph :
Incorrect: A chest radiograph would be indicated if there were concerns for pulmonary pathology. Though the patient’s respiratory rate is elevated, the examination points toward a neurological issue. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine :
Incorrect: An MRI of the thoracic spine would be indicated if there were symptoms suggestive of spinal cord compression or other spinal pathology. The patient's symptoms and history do not suggest a thoracic spinal issue but rather an intracranial condition. 
❌ Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level :
Incorrect: While thyroid dysfunction can lead to changes in metabolic and neurological status, this patient’s acute presentation with neurological signs including papilledema and confusion points more directly toward an intracranial process. Thus, TSH levels would not be the priority test in this scenario.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents to the emergency department with progressive swelling, dyspnea, and muscle weakness in both legs. He has also had episodes of palpitations and paresthesias today. He has missed several dialysis appointments this week due to a lack of transportation. Temperature is 37 ℃ (98.6 ℉), heart rate is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure 152/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On examination, rales are heard throughout the bilateral lung fields. 2+ pitting edema is noted in both lower extremities and there is decreased strength in the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory studies are notable for a creatinine of 13 mg/dL and potassium of 7.5 mEq/L. An ECG taken during triage is shown below. Which of the following medications should be immediately administered?  


Wikimediacommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of leg weakness, palpitations, and paresthesias in the setting of missed hemodialysis is concerning for hyperkalemia. In addition to a potassium level of 7.5 mEq/L, the ECG demonstrates tall, peaked T waves and small (and in some leads, indiscernible) P waves, indicating an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmia. IV calcium gluconate should be administered immediately to stabilize the myocardium.  

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium concentration ≥ 5.5 mEq/L. Patients with mild hyperkalemia may be asymptomatic. However, patients with severe hyperkalemia (> 7 mEq/L) can present with palpitations, paresthesias, muscle weakness, and even ascending paralysis. Cardiac conduction abnormalities or arrhythmias can also occur, and ECG findings may include tall, peaked T waves, ST segment depression, PR prolongation, loss of P waves, and QRS widening. These ECG changes can progress to a sine wave pattern and asystole.  

There are 3 main goals in the management of hyperkalemia: stabilize the myocardium, shift potassium into cells quickly, and remove potassium from the body. Calcium gluconate stabilizes cardiac cell membranes, so it is given immediately to patients with ECG changes, cardiac arrhythmias, or in the case of severe hyperkalemia. Insulin, albuterol, and/or sodium bicarbonate are used to shift potassium into cells to reduce serum potassium levels. These are temporizing measures and are useful in cases like this while awaiting definitive treatment with dialysis. Other treatments that remove potassium from the body include diuretics (e.g. furosemide), and potassium binders (e.g. oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate).  

Option Analysis

✅ IV calcium gluconate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ IV regular insulin:
Incorrect: IV regular insulin (plus dextrose) is utilized for the treatment of hyperkalemia and acts by shifting potassium into cells. Given the ECG changes, IV calcium gluconate should be given immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia, then insulin and dextrose can be given.
❌ Nebulized albuterol:
Incorrect: Nebulized albuterol can be used to treat hyperkalemia, and acts by shifting potassium into cells. However, given the ECG changes, calcium gluconate should be given immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia, then nebulized albuterol can be given.  
❌ IV sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: IV sodium bicarbonate can be used to treat hyperkalemia, and acts by shifting potassium into cells. Given the ECG changes, calcium gluconate should be given immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia, then IV sodium bicarbonate can be given if necessary.  
❌ Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate:
Incorrect: Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate is a potassium binder that increases fecal excretion of potassium. In this case, dialysis would be the preferred way to remove potassium from the body. Given the ECG changes, calcium gluconate should be administered immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic due to fatigue, paresthesias in the hands and feet, and intermittent abdominal cramps for the past two months. His past medical history is significant for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He hasn’t been seen by primary care in over 2 years and takes no medications. Vitals are significant for blood pressure of 170/90. Physical examination is significant for spasms of the left hand when the blood pressure cuff is inflated above the systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes. Laboratory evaluation is significant for creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL (previously 1.7 mg/dL). Which of the following is most likely to be seen on further blood work analysis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, HTN, and kidney disease presents with fatigue, intermittent cramps, and carpopedal spasm with inflation of the blood pressure cuff (positive Trousseau sign). This clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of hypocalcemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.  

Important causes of hypocalcemia include hypomagnesemia, impaired vitamin D conversion, hypoparathyroidism, and secondary hyperparathyroidism. When evaluating patients with hypocalcemia, magnesium should be checked first. If it is not the cause of hypocalcemia, then additional lab work including a basic metabolic panel, serum PTH and 25-hydroxy vitamin D (inactive form of Vitamin D) should be checked. If the serum creatinine is elevated, then the active form of vitamin D or 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, should be checked. If CKD is the cause of hypocalcemia, then 1,25 hydroxy vitamin D level will be low and the PTH level will be increased in response to the low calcium level.     

Hypocalcemia in CKD arises from two primary mechanisms: decreased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D and hyperphosphatemia. CKD impairs the kidney's ability to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in response to parathyroid hormone (PTH). This active form of vitamin D is necessary for intestinal absorption of calcium. As levels of active vitamin D drop, less calcium is absorbed from the gut, leading to hypocalcemia. CKD also reduces the kidney's ability to excrete phosphate, leading to hyperphosphatemia. Elevated phosphate levels can also precipitate calcium, further lowering serum calcium levels. The decrease in serum calcium stimulates PTH secretion in an attempt to restore calcium homeostasis.  

Option Analysis

✅  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D  Decreased  Increased  Increased  Decreased :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D   Decreased  Increased  Increased  Normal:
Incorrect: Decreased calcium, increased phosphate, increased PTH, and normal 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D reflects hyperphosphatemia. Patients with CKD may have hyperphosphatemia, typically accompanied by decreased 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels due to impaired renal conversion.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH  Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D  Decreased  Increased  Decreased    Normal:
Incorrect: Decreased calcium, increased phosphate, decreased PTH, and normal 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels suggest a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism. However, this patient with CKD likely has hypocalcemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH  Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D  Decreased  Decreased  Increased  Decreased :
Incorrect: Decreased calcium and phosphate with increased PTH suggest secondary hyperparathyroidism due to Vitamin D deficiency. However, the patient's elevated creatinine in the setting of type 2 DM and HTN makes chronic kidney disease a more likely cause of his hypocalcemia.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH  Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D Increased  Decreased  Increased  Normal:
Incorrect: Increased calcium, decreased phosphate, and increased PTH suggest primary hyperparathyroidism, which does not align with the patient's presentation of hypocalcemia and kidney disease.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for routine follow up. The patient does not take any medications. The patient has chronic diarrhea for which no cause has yet been identified despite evaluation that the patient and patient’s mother have requested. Temperature is 36.7 °C (98.0 °F), heart rate is 98/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is thin and has dry lips. Laboratory studies obtained at the last visit are listed below. Which of the following conditions would be most consistent with these findings?  

 Laboratory study  Result
 Serum potassium  3.0 mEq/L 
 TSH  1.2 microunits/mL 
 Urine potassium:creatinine  1.1
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic, unexplained diarrhea, mild hypokalemia, and evidence of mild volume depletion. The urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio is < 1.5, signifying extrarenal potassium wasting. The only answer choice that meets this criterion is surreptitious laxative use, which would also explain the patient’s chronic diarrhea.   

There are many potential causes of hypokalemia. Often, this can be elicited from the history and presentation (e.g. decreased potassium intake, recent GI illness, diuretic use). If the cause is not obvious, additional workup should be obtained. Evaluation should start with a serum magnesium level to rule out hypomagnesemia. From there, patients can be evaluated for potential causes of transcellular potassium shifts. This should include reviewing medications (e.g. theophylline, beta agonists, insulin) or evaluating for conditions like hyperthyroidism, which may be accompanied by symptoms (e.g. heat intolerance, palpitations) and a low TSH.    

If these causes are ruled out, the next step is to obtain urine studies in order to calculate the urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio. If it is ≤ 1.5, extrarenal potassium wasting is most likely, which can be caused by laxative overuse, other causes of severe diarrhea, and excessive sweating. If the ratio is > 1.5, then a condition that causes renal potassium wasting is more likely. In patients with hypertension or evidence of hypervolemia, consider diseases affecting mineralocorticoid activity, such as Cushing syndrome, hyperaldosteronism, and congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Otherwise, the next step is to check the patient’s acid-base status. Metabolic acidosis is associated with renal tubular acidosis and acetazolamide use. Metabolic alkalosis is associated with Bartter and Gitelman syndrome as well as diuretics.   

Option Analysis

✅ Surreptitious laxative use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism can cause hypokalemia through transcellular potassium shifts. However, this would be associated with a low TSH. This patient’s TSH is normal.  
❌ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can cause hypokalemia due to increased mineralocorticoid activity. However, the urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be > 1.5.   
❌ Gitelman syndrome:
Incorrect: Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that results in renal potassium wasting. The urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be > 1.5.  
❌ Bartter syndrome:
Incorrect: Bartter syndrome causes hypokalemia through renal potassium wasting. The urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be > 1.5.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness and muscle cramps. The patient has intentionally lost 25 lbs (11.3 kg) in the past 3 months. She has a history of obesity and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. She appears weak, but is able to respond to questions appropriately. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and diminished skin turgor. Her neck appears supple. She has multiple abrasions on her hands. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Initial laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum Chemistry

Sodium
125 mEq/L
Potassium
3.0 mEq/L  
Chloride
84 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
40 mEq/L  
Serum Osmolality  
270 mOsm/kg  
Urine Chemistry  

Urine sodium  
15 mEq/L  
Urine chloride  
3 mEq/L  
Urine osmolality  
560 mOsm/kg
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of weakness and muscle cramps with physical examination findings of dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, borderline low blood pressure, and serum sodium of 125 mEq/L are concerning for hypovolemic hyponatremia. Given her intentional weight loss of 25 lbs in 3 months, metabolic alkalosis, urine sodium < 20 mEq/L, and abrasions on her hands, surreptitious vomiting is the most likely cause of hyponatremia.

For patients with hyponatremia, a focused history and examination should assess for symptoms of cerebral edema, which usually presents as headache, nausea, vomiting and/or confusion. If any of these are present, patients should be treated emergently with boluses of hypertonic saline. Assessment of volume status can usually guide the clinician towards the probable cause of hyponatremia and differentiate between hypovolemic, euvolemic or hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Laboratory evaluation can further narrow down the differential diagnosis. For patients with hypovolemia, the body typically responds by secreting antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which stimulates reabsorption of free water in the kidneys, causing urine osmolality to rise. However, in patients with non-renal sodium loss (e.g. vomiting) the urine sodium levels are < 20 mEq/L, as seen in this case.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Surreptitious vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diuretic use:
Incorrect: This patient has hypovolemia with metabolic alkalosis which can occur in patients with ongoing diuretic use. These patients would also have loss of sodium in the urine leading to a urine sodium of > 20 mEq/L. This patient’s urine sodium is 15 mEq/L, and thus surreptitious vomiting is more likely the cause of hyponatremia.  
❌ Mineralocorticoid deficiency:
Incorrect: This patient has hypovolemia with metabolic alkalosis which can occur in patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency. However, loss of sodium in the urine typically leads to a urine sodium of > 20 mEq/L with mineralocorticoid deficiency. This patient’s urine sodium is 15 mEq/L and thus surreptitious vomiting is more likely the cause of hyponatremia.  
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH):
Incorrect: Patients with SIADH are usually euvolemic, and excessive reabsorption of free water leads to an elevated concentration of sodium in the urine (urine sodium > 20 mEq/L). This patient appears hypovolemic on examination and has a urine sodium of 15 mEq/L, making hypovolemic hyponatremia from surreptitious vomiting more likely.  
❌ Primary polydipsia:
Incorrect: Excessive water intake in patients with primary polydipsia can cause urine sodium to decline < 20 mEq/L. However, patients with primary polydipsia typically appear euvolemic on examination. This patient more than likely has hypovolemic hyponatremia from surreptitious vomiting.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for an annual visit. He has a chronic cough but no other complaints. Review of systems is significant for 20 lbs (9 kg) unintentional weight loss over the past 6 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and diabetes mellitus type 2. He takes valsartan, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin and metformin. He is a current smoker with a 55 pack-year history. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes without lower extremity edema. Cardiac examination is unremarkable. Routine labs show a serum sodium of 126 mEq/dL. Results from laboratory testing are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum

Blood urea nitrogen  
9 mg/dL
Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL  
Osmolality
257 mOsm/kg H2O  
Cortisol, 8AM  
15.1 mcg/dL (normal)  
ACTH, 8AM  
40 pmol/L (normal)  
TSH
3 mIU/L  
Urine

Osmolality
420 mOsm/kg  
Sodium
45 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic euvolemic hyponatremia and significant weight loss with normal adrenal and thyroid function, suggesting syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). An occult lung malignancy with paraneoplastic syndrome is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient.

Initial diagnostic workup for hyponatremia involves evaluating serum osmolality. If the serum osmolality is <280 mOsm/kg, a diagnosis of true hyponatremia can be established. Assessment of volume status can further narrow down the differential diagnoses for causes of hyponatremia.

This patient appears euvolemic on examination, with a urine sodium of > 20mEq and urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg. In the absence of hypothyroidism or secondary adrenal insufficiency, these values indicate an abnormally high ADH. This will cause continuous reabsorption of water through ADH-stimulated aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting duct and lead to further increases of sodium in the urine and urine osmolality. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) from paraneoplastic syndrome caused by small cell lung cancer can lead to hyponatremia, and this patient should be further evaluated with chest imaging.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Low dietary solute intake:
Incorrect: Low dietary solute intake can result in a relative increase in free water in the extracellular fluid and hyponatremia. The kidneys respond by increasing the reabsorption of filtered sodium, which results in a urine sodium < 20 mEq/L. Urine osmolality typically declines to < 100 mOsm/kg. This patient’s urine sodium is 45 mEq/L and urine osmolality is 420 mOsm/kg. Given his history and physical examination, SIADH from a lung malignancy is more likely.  
❌ Mineralocorticoid deficiency:
Incorrect: Patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency develop hyponatremia, concomitant hypovolemia and metabolic alkalosis and will typically have low blood pressure and hypokalemia. These signs and symptoms are absent in this patient, and he is euvolemic. Given his history and physical examination, SIADH from a lung malignancy is more likely.  
✅ Occult lung malignancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surreptitious vomiting:
Incorrect: Surreptitious vomiting usually results in hypovolemic hyponatremia and urine sodium < 20 mEq/L. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a urine sodium >20 mEq/L.  
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Patients with heart failure and hyponatremia usually appear hypervolemic on exam and have a urine sodium below 20 mEq/L. This patient is euvolemic with a urine sodium of 45 mEq/L. Given his history and physical examination, SIADH from a lung malignancy is more likely.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son after he was found confused on the floor of his apartment. The patient is lethargic but responsive and reports nausea, vomiting, and generalized weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, and chronic kidney disease. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg. Laboratory results and ECG are shown below. The patient is immediately started on intravenous calcium gluconate. Administration of which of the following additional agents is indicated in this patient?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum chemistry  

Sodium
142 mEq/L
Potassium
7.5 mEq/L  
Chloride
95 mEq/L  
Creatinine
4.5 mg/dL  
BUN
49


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with hyperkalemia (serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L and peaked T waves on ECG). Emergent treatment with intravenous calcium gluconate is indicated in this patient to stabilize the cardiac myocytes and prevent arrhythmias. Intravenous insulin with glucose and/or inhaled beta-2 agonists are used to transiently shift potassium into the cells and lower serum potassium levels.

Inhaled beta-adrenergic agonists (e.g. albuterol) shift potassium intracellularly by stimulating the Na+/K+ ATPase. It can also stimulate the release of insulin, which further promotes intracellular shifts of potassium. A significantly higher dose of nebulizer is required as compared to the dose used for the treatment of asthma or COPD. It is indicated as a 3rd line medication for hyperkalemia and should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease due to the risk of tachycardia-induced angina.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor that decreases the excretion of potassium by decreasing aldosterone secretion. Its administration will further increase serum potassium levels.  
✅ Albuterol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic blocker that interferes with Β2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake. It is not indicated for the management of hyperkalemia.  
❌ Digitalis:
Incorrect: Digitalis is an inotropic agent which inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase to block intracellular uptake of potassium. Its administration may further increase serum potassium levels, among other side effects.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin should be avoided in this patient with chronic kidney disease. It will decrease renal perfusion and may cause further accumulation of serum potassium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion, dizziness and blurred vision. The patient’s medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, and she does not take medication. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 108/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds in the lungs bilaterally with no crackles or wheezes. Neurological examination is significant for decreased visual acuity and nystagmus. The patient’s laboratory studies are shown below. Based on the patient's presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following conditions should be included in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s laboratory studies reveal a non-compensated metabolic acidosis (low pH and bicarbonate, relatively normal PaCO2) with a high anion gap. Of the answer choices provided, only methanol intoxication would result in these laboratory findings.

Metabolic acidosis is a clinical disturbance characterized by a reduced blood pH (< 7.35) and decreased serum bicarbonate (HCO3-) level. This may or may not be associated with a compensatory decrease in partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) due to increased respiratory rate as the body attempts to restore acid-base balance. An essential step in the evaluation of metabolic acidosis is calculating the anion gap, which is the difference between the primary measured cations (sodium) and the primary measured anions (chloride and bicarbonate). The anion gap is calculated using the formula: Na+ - Cl- - HCO3-. A normal anion gap is typically between 8 and 12 mEq/L.

An increased anion gap metabolic acidosis indicates the presence of unmeasured anions and is often due to the accumulation of organic acids. The mnemonic "MUDPILES" is a useful tool to remember the common causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Identifying whether metabolic acidosis is a high anion gap or a normal anion gap is crucial in narrowing the differential diagnosis and guiding further clinical investigation and management.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Methanol intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acetazolamide use:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide use can result in a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis via excess bicarbonate loss in urine. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: Diarrhea can cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis via excess bicarbonate loss in stool. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Renal tubular acidosis can cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Addison disease:
Incorrect: Addison disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, can cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of two days of abdominal pain, nausea, malaise, and increased thirst. Symptoms were initially intermittent at onset but are now constant. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not currently take any medications. Temperature is 37.6 ºC (99.7 ºF), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Mucous membranes are dry, and there is decreased skin turgor. There is mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is given one liter of 0.9% saline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Serum Laboratory Test     Result   
 Sodium     124 mEq/L    
 Chloride     96 mEq/L    
 Potassium     5.5 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     14 mEq/L    
 Glucose     500 mg/dL    
 Beta-hydroxybutyrate     5 mmol/L (normal < 0.5 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain, nausea, and polydipsia presents with an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis with severe hyperglycemia and ketosis. Together, these findings indicate diabetic ketoacidosis, and the most appropriate treatment is an insulin infusion and IV fluid hydration (0.9% saline in this case).

Metabolic acidosis refers to an increase in hydrogen ions and a decrease in bicarbonate concentration in the blood due to a metabolic cause. Metabolic acidosis can be classified as non- (or normal) anion gap or elevated (or high) anion gap. The anion gap is calculated by subtracting the concentrations of serum chloride and bicarbonate from serum sodium (AG = Na - Cl - HCO3).

Patients presenting acutely with metabolic acidosis can be extremely ill. They are often tachypneic as the body tries to compensate by inducing a relative respiratory alkalosis. An ABCDE assessment is crucial at the time of presentation. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for most patients presenting with acute metabolic acidosis. Once stabilized, the underlying issues causing metabolic acidosis should be addressed to prevent decompensation. Severe, untreated metabolic acidosis can lead to cardiac arrest.

Life-threatening causes of metabolic acidosis include toxic ingestion (e.g., ethylene glycol, methanol, isoniazid, salicylates), septic shock with resultant lactic acidosis, severe acute kidney injury, and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Patients with DKA are typically volume-depleted, requiring aggressive IV fluid resuscitation. Insulin infusion is crucial for stopping the production of ketones and the resultant acidosis. Once the patient’s anion gap is closed, they can be transitioned to subcutaneous insulin for continued management of hyperglycemia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Insulin infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 0.45% saline infusion:
Incorrect: Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis should receive IV fluid hydration with 0.9% or 0.45% saline based upon the corrected sodium level (i.e., when accounting for hyperglycemia). This patient is hypovolemic and the corrected sodium level of 132 is still below the normal reference range, so 0.9% saline is more appropriate. 
❌ Oral sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Administration of oral sodium bicarbonate can help treat patients with chronic metabolic acidosis from chronic kidney disease. Bicarbonate administration is not necessary for this patient. 
❌ Subcutaneous insulin:
Incorrect: Diabetic ketoacidosis can be managed with subcutaneous insulin in mild cases if an insulin infusion is not feasible. However, insulin infusion is the safest and most reliable method of insulin delivery. 
❌ Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal potassium binders are the cornerstone of treatment of hyperkalemia. This patient has mild hyperkalemia which will resolve after initiation of an insulin infusion, so a potassium binder is not necessary in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for abdominal pain, vomiting, and frequent urination over the last 24 hours. Over the past several days, he has been much more thirsty than usual and has experienced severe fatigue. He has no burning with urination. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs and has not recently taken any supplements. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 99/62 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Abdominal exam reveals mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Neurological exam is nonfocal. Basic metabolic panel is obtained and shows sodium 128 mEq/L, chloride 91 mEq/L, and bicarbonate 14 mEq/L. Which of the following additional historical or physical examination findings is likely to be present given the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, polyuria, and polydipsia and is found to have an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. Together, this patient’s symptoms and elevated anion gap are highly suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. This typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM), who often have a family history of type 1 DM or other autoimmune diseases.

Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) usually present with signs of hyperglycemia (polyuria, polydipsia), fatigue, and GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain). Altered mental status can occur but is more common in a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. Since DKA is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus, patients may have a family history of type 1 diabetes mellitus or a personal or family history of other autoimmune diseases.

On physical examination, patients will be uncomfortable-appearing and may have altered mentation. They are usually tachypneic as the body tries to compensate for metabolic acidosis by inducing a relative respiratory alkalosis. The mucous membranes are typically very dry as patients can be extremely volume-depleted. Generalized abdominal tenderness is common. Tachycardia and hypotension are also common due to the severe volume depletion which is often seen.   

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of type 1 diabetes:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acetazolamide use:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide can lead to metabolic acidosis due to increased urinary bicarbonate wasting. This causes a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis; however, this patient has an elevated anion gap. 
❌ Recent weight gain:
Incorrect: This patient likely has new-onset type 1 diabetes mellitus presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis. New type 1 diabetes mellitus is typically associated with weight loss and not weight gain. 
❌ Decreased visual acuity:
Incorrect: Decreased visual acuity can occur in patients with methanol toxicity and can eventually lead to blindness. This could cause this patient’s elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, the clinical presentation of abdominal pain, polyuria, and polydipsia is more suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. Symptoms that suggest methanol toxicity include neurologic symptoms like those seen with alcohol intoxication, such as disinhibition, ataxia, drowsiness, and seizures. 
❌ History of kidney stones:
Incorrect: Recurrent kidney stones in a patient with metabolic acidosis could indicate renal tubular acidosis. This would, however, cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, and this patient has an elevated anion gap.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of bilateral leg swelling and increased abdominal girth. The symptoms started around 2-weeks ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for liver cirrhosis that has been well-managed with furosemide for the past 4-years. The patient has also taken over-the-counter ibuprofen for the past few weeks due to back strain. The patient has not made any changes to dietary sodium or fluid intake. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral +2 pitting edema and moderate ascites. Laboratory evaluations reveal decreased fractional excretion of sodium. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of liver cirrhosis well-managed with furosemide developed worsening lower extremity edema and ascites over the past 2-weeks. These symptoms are likely due to recent ibuprofen use.       

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Loop diuretics also increase the synthesis of prostaglandin in the afferent renal arterioles to increase renal blood flow (RBF), glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and NaCl excretion via the urine.        

In healthy patients, NSAIDs (e.g. ibuprofen) have minimal effect on renal perfusion due to low prostaglandin synthesis. However, in patients with intravascular volume depletion (e.g., cirrhosis, dehydration), the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis by NSAIDs results in a markedly decreased RBF and GFR. These effects result in reduced delivery of fluids and electrolytes to the renal tubule, thereby causing water and salt retention as well as symptoms of volume overload in susceptible patients.    

Option Analysis

❌ Insufficient dose of furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient’s condition has been well-managed with furosemide for the past 4 years. The deterioration of his condition is most likely a result of reduced renal blood flow and glomerular filtration secondary to recent ibuprofen use. 
✅ Use of ibuprofen for pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Incompetent venous valves:
Incorrect: Varicose veins are dilated, tortuous, subcutaneous veins that result from incompetent venous valves in the lower extremity. No such veins were identified on physical examination. In contrast, the progressively worsening lower extremity edema and ascites in this patient is more suggestive of fluid retention secondary to NSAID administration. 
❌ Occlusion of the hepatic veins:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome results from occlusion of the hepatic veins. Although it can present with abdominal ascites and lower extremity edema, patients typically also have abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and jaundice. The deterioration of this patient’s condition is more likely due to reduced renal blood flow and glomerular filtration secondary to ibuprofen intake. 
❌ Thrombosis of the deep veins :
Incorrect: Deep vein thrombosis usually presents with unilateral lower extremity pain, erythema, and tenderness. It does not present with ascites or bilateral lower extremity edema.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with severe pneumonia and is placed on mechanical ventilation. His initial ventilator settings include a tidal volume of 700 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, FiO2 of 50%, and PEEP of 8 cm H2O. On the morning of the second day, he appears comfortable and is sedated. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 112 beats/minute, blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and oxygen saturation is 95%. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally with occasional crackles noted at the lung bases. There is no evidence of accessory muscle use, and his extremities are warm and well-perfused. Arterial blood gas (ABG) results are reviewed, and the decision is made to decrease the tidal volume. Which of the following is the most likely set of ABG results that prompted this decision?
questions.solution:
In the context of mechanical ventilation, reducing a patient’s tidal volume in response to ABG results indicates that the current settings were causing hyperventilation. As a result, this patient’s expected ABG would have shown a respiratory alkalosis, characterized by an elevated pH of 7.52 and a reduced PaCO2 of 19 mEq/L as seen in answer choice A. This finding would have prompted the clinicians to reduce the tidal volume.

Respiratory alkalosis is a condition characterized by a decrease in arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO2 < 35 mm Hg) due to excessive alveolar ventilation, leading to an increase in blood pH (> 7.45). Bicarbonate levels may be normal or slightly decreased as a compensatory mechanism. Common etiologies of respiratory alkalosis include psychogenic hyperventilation, pulmonary disease, drug toxicity, central nervous system disorders, and iatrogenic factors such as inappropriate ventilator settings.

Iatrogenic respiratory alkalosis can occur when ventilator settings result in excessive alveolar ventilation. The primary settings that affect this are tidal volume and respiratory rate. If either of these are set too high, they may contribute to a decrease in PaCO2. This can be corrected by turning down the tidal volume or respiratory rate. Thus, ABG monitoring is essential to recognize and correct potential acid-base disturbances that may occur in mechanically ventilated patients.   

Option Analysis

✅  Laboratory test     Result     pH     7.52     PaCO2     28 mm Hg     PaO2     90 mm Hg     HCO3     19 mEq/L    :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌  Laboratory test     Result     pH     7.44     PaCO2     40 mm Hg     PaO2     95 mm Hg     HCO3     24 mEq/L    :
Incorrect: This ABG result shows normal values, suggesting adequate ventilation and gas exchange. There is no indication of hyperventilation or alkalosis, so a change in tidal volume based on these results would not be necessary. 
❌  Laboratory test     Result     pH     7.25     PaCO2     55 mm Hg     PaO2     80 mm Hg     HCO3     28 mEq/L    :
Incorrect: This ABG result indicates respiratory acidosis, which suggests inadequate ventilation rather than excessive ventilation. This situation would typically prompt an increase in ventilatory support, not a decrease in tidal volume. 
❌  Laboratory test     Result     pH     7.38     PaCO2     46 mm Hg     PaO2     50 mm Hg     HCO3     25 mEq/L    :
Incorrect: This ABG result is most significant for hypoxemia, indicating poor oxygenation. In this case, an increase in PEEP or FiO2 would be necessary, rather than decreasing tidal volume. 
❌  Laboratory test     Result     pH     7.31     PaCO2     36 mm Hg     PaO2     90 mm Hg     HCO3     16 mEq/L    :
Incorrect: This ABG result shows metabolic acidosis with a compensatory decrease in PaCO2. The primary issue here is metabolic rather than respiratory and decreasing the tidal volume would not address the underlying metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman with hypertension presents to the emergency department due to persistent diarrhea and vomiting and one day of generalized weakness and muscle cramps. The patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms started three days ago and several family members have had similar symptoms. The patient has not been able to tolerate much oral intake during this period but has been able to take her daily hydrochlorothiazide dose with a little water. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), heart rate is 60/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 100/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient’s lips are dry and skin turgor is reduced. Laboratory studies and an ECG obtained during triage are shown below. What is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory Study  Result 
 Sodium  130 mEq/L 
 Potassium  2.0 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.8 mg/dL 



Wikidoc

choices.text: Place the patient on cardiac monitoring

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe hypokalemia in the setting of vomiting, diarrhea, poor oral intake, and ongoing thiazide diuretic use. The patient also has associated weakness; muscle cramps; and ECG findings of low T wave amplitude, ST segment depressions, and U waves. This patient is at risk for arrhythmias, including severe bradycardia, ventricular tachycardia (including torsades de pointes), and ventricular fibrillation. Thus, placing the patient on cardiac monitoring is the most important first step in management.  

Hypokalemia is defined as a serum potassium level < 3.5 mEq/L. Mild hypokalemia is often asymptomatic. Severe hypokalemia can result in muscle weakness, cramps, ascending paralysis, and arrhythmias. There are a number of potential causes of hypokalemia, including but not limited to medications (e.g. diuretics, laxatives), decreased oral intake, excessive GI losses, transcellular shifts of potassium, and renal losses.    

When evaluating a patient with hypokalemia, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. IV access should be obtained, and cardiac monitoring should be started. Severe muscle weakness can result in respiratory failure, so endotracheal intubation may be necessary in severe cases. Hemodynamic stabilization and arrhythmia management are imperative. In patients who are unable to tolerate oral intake or have severe symptoms or ECG changes, IV potassium replacement should be given. Otherwise, oral potassium replacement can be given. Additionally, a serum magnesium level should be checked as hypomagnesemia can exacerbate rhythm disturbances and prevent adequate potassium replacement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Place the patient on cardiac monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prescribe oral potassium chloride:
Incorrect: This patient’s potassium level is severely low, resulting in ECG changes. Oral potassium replacement can be given, but initial replacement should be intravenous. The patient should be placed on a cardiac monitor emergently to monitor for arrhythmias.  
❌ Start IV 0.9% saline infusion:
Incorrect: While the patient does have evidence of volume depletion and could benefit from IV fluids, management of severe hypokalemia with ECG changes takes precedence.   
❌ Prescribe IV ondansetron:
Incorrect: While an antiemetic could help this patient’s symptoms, management of the severe hypokalemia with ECG changes takes precedence.   
❌ Prescribe oral loperamide:
Incorrect: Management of this patient’s severe hypokalemia with ECG changes should occur before symptomatic treatment of diarrhea.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after developing a headache, confusion, nausea and vomiting while running a marathon. The patient felt like he had to stop running at mile 22 and subsequently had two episodes of non-bilious, non-bloody emesis. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medication. Temperature is 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 111/70 mm Hg, pulse rate is 105/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient appears confused. Physical examination reveals significant perspiration. Initial laboratory evaluation shows a serum sodium  level of 117 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, headache and confusion in the setting of hyponatremia.  These findings are concerning for cerebral edema in the setting of acute hyponatremia. The most appropriate next step in management is administration of an intravenous 100-mL bolus of 3% (hypertonic) saline.

Hyponatremia is a common electrolyte disturbance where the serum sodium concentration is less than 135 milliequivalents per liter. It can be acute (within 24 - 48 hours) or chronic (more than 48 hours). An acute drop in sodium can result in water moving into brain parenchyma, producing cerebral edema and causing symptoms such as headache, seizure, and coma.

Common causes of acute hyponatremia include postoperative states, extreme exercise (e.g. marathon runners), administration of oxytocin, bowel preparations or thiazide diuretics, intake of excessive amounts of water (primary polydipsia) and ecstasy use. Patients with acute symptomatic hyponatremia should be treated with a 100-mL bolus of 3% saline. If symptoms do not improve and the sodium remains low, additional boluses can be given. The goal is to increase the sodium level by at least 1-2 mEq/L/hr until resolution of symptoms, and then to increase the sodium level more slowly after that.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous 100-mL bolus of 3% (hypertonic) saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fluid restriction:
Incorrect: Fluid restriction may allow for slow correction of serum sodium; however, it should not be the sole treatment for patients with acute symptomatic hyponatremia.  
❌ Intravenous 0.9% saline:
Incorrect: For patients with acute hyponatremia, serum ADH is expected to be high, which induces water reabsorption in the kidneys with a significant elevation in urine osmolality. It can exceed the osmolality of normal saline (~280-300 mOsm/L), and has the potential to further lower the patient’s sodium. Use of 0.9% saline should be limited to those patients with evidence of volume depletion and minimal symptoms.  
❌ Immersion in ice water:
Incorrect: Immersion in ice water can be considered for young patients with exertional heat stroke when they remain symptomatic despite evaporative cooling measures. This patient with a body temperature of 100.4 °F is less likely to be suffering from exertional heat stroke.  
❌ Intravenous 0.45% saline:
Incorrect: In patients with acute hyponatremia, serum ADH is expected to be high, which causes water reabsorption in kidneys and significant elevation in urine osmolality. 0.45% saline can exceed the osmolality of normal saline (~140 mOsm/L), it has the potential to further lower the patient’s sodium.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of lower back pain. Review of systems is significant for poor appetite and a 10 lbs (4.5 kg) weight loss over the past 6 months. The patient had a resection of a localized meningioma 2 years ago without complications or recurrence. The patient does not take any medication. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes, pallor, and midline tenderness upon palpation at L3 and L4. There is pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the knees. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable without jugular venous distension (JVD). Laboratory results are shown below. A urine dipstick is negative for proteinuria. Radiograph of the spine shows a lytic bone lesion in the L4 vertebral body. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum Chemistry   

Sodium
128 mEq/L
Potassium
3.7 mEq/L  
Chloride
100 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
25 mEq/L  
Calcium
11 mg/dL  
Blood urea nitrogen  
20 mg/dL  
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL  
Total protein  
8.5 g/dL  
Albumin
2.5 g/dL  
Serum Osmolality  
285 mOsm/kg  
Complete Blood Count   

Hemoglobin
8.0 g/dL  
Leukocyte count  
10,000/mm3   
Platelets
180,000/mm3   
Urine electrolytes   

Sodium
18 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with low back pain and radiographic evidence of lytic bone lesions. These findings, together with poor appetite, weight loss and anemia, suggest undiagnosed multiple myeloma. Given the elevated protein gap (difference between total protein and albumin > 4 g/dL) and normal serum osmolality (between 280-295 mOsm/kg), pseudohyponatremia from paraproteinemia appears to be the most likely explanation for this patient's low sodium.

Pseudohyponatremia rarely occurs and refers to a lab artifact caused by high serum levels of triglycerides or protein, which can displace free water in plasma, resulting in an inaccurate measurement of sodium levels. When evaluating hyponatremia, a serum osmolality should be obtained. If there is a normal serum osmolality, then pseudohyponatremia is the likely cause and serum triglyceride and protein levels should be measured to confirm the diagnosis.

On the other hand, if plasma osmolality levels rise above 295 mmol/kg, this indicates the presence of other osmotically active solutes, like glucose or mannitol. Hyperosmolarity causes an osmotic shift of water from the intracellular space to extracellular fluid, causing dilutional hyponatremia. If serum osmolality falls below 280 mmol/kg, a diagnosis of true hyponatremia can be made.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pseudohyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surreptitious vomiting:
Incorrect: Surreptitious vomiting usually results in hypovolemic hyponatremia, and the serum osmolality is typically < 275 mmol/kg. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L, which is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.  
❌ Mineralocorticoid deficiency:
Incorrect: Patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency typically have evidence of hypovolemia and metabolic alkalosis, as well as loss of sodium in urine, causing urine sodium levels to be > 20 mEq/L. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L and urine sodium level < 20 mEq/L which is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.  
❌ Cerebral salt wasting:
Incorrect: Cerebral salt wasting occurs with an insult to the central nervous system in the form of trauma, recent surgery, or hemorrhage. The exact cause is unknown, but patients typically are hypovolemic and have a urine sodium of > 20 mEq/L. This patient’s meningioma resection was 2 years ago, the patient appears euvolemic on exam, and the serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L and urine sodium level of < 20 mEq/L; taken together, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.  
❌ Renal failure:
Incorrect: Renal failure causes true hyponatremia where serum osmolality is < 275 mmol/kg, and patients appear hypervolemic on examination due to volume retention, and have elevated urine sodium levels due to impaired resorption. In addition, BUN/creatinine is typically elevated. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a serum osmolality of 285 mEq/L and urine sodium level < 20 mEq/L, which is more consistent with pseudohyponatremia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe thirst and production of large volumes of urine over the past month. She has bipolar disorder and has been on lithium therapy for several years. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination her mucus membranes appear dry; the exam is otherwise unremarkable. A point-of-care glucose check is 88 mg/dL. The physician suspects the patient’s condition is likely caused by lithium and orders an initial set of laboratory studies to evaluate. Which of the following sets of laboratory results would best support their suspicion?

choices.text: Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  150 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  700 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  126 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  270 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  100 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  128 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  320 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  800 mOsm/kg
Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  125 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  265 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  500 mOsm/kg

questions.solution:
Polydipsia and polyuria together in the setting of lithium therapy is concerning for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Initial laboratory findings to support this diagnosis would include elevated serum sodium and osmolality combined with low urine osmolality.   

Laboratory findings for DI typically include elevated serum sodium and osmolality alongside low urine osmolality (usually < 300 mOsm/kg), reflecting the inability to concentrate urine. Water deprivation testing can differentiate DI from other water balance disorders (e.g. primary polydipsia), particularly in cases where initial laboratory results are relatively normal. In primary polydipsia, restricting free water intake will stimulate ADH release to maximally concentrate the urine (thus, raising urine osmolality). This process is impaired in DI, so if the urine osmolality remains low the next step is to perform a desmopressin challenge to determine if DI is central or nephrogenic. In central DI, desmopressin (a synthetic form of ADH) compensates for the lack of endogenous ADH and raises urine osmolality. Conversely, in nephrogenic DI there is little to no change in the urine osmolality as the kidneys cannot respond to ADH or its analogs.  

Option Analysis

✅  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  150 mOsm/kg :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  150 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  310 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  700 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: High urine osmolality in the presence of elevated serum sodium and osmolality suggests an effective concentration of urine, which could be seen in patients with dehydration who still retain the ability to concentrate urine adequately. However, lithium is associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus which is characterized by an inability to concentrate urine.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  126 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  270 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  100 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: The presence of low serum sodium and osmolality alongside low urine osmolality could indicate primary polydipsia. However, the patient in this vignette is more likely to have nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to lithium use.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  128 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  320 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  800 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: This pattern could suggest an osmotic diuresis process (such as hyperglycemia). However, the patient in this vignette is more likely to have nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to lithium use.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Serum sodium  125 mEq/L  Serum osmolality  265 mOsm/kg  Urine osmolality (baseline)  500 mOsm/kg :
Incorrect: Markedly low serum sodium and osmolality with a relatively normal urine osmolality might suggest a syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) where water retention leads to dilutional hyponatremia. The kidneys are concentrating urine relative to the serum, which contrasts with the expected findings in lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to weakness for the past few months. He has intermittent, mild achiness throughout his abdomen that tends to come and go. Past medical history is significant for delayed growth throughout childhood and recurrent kidney stones. The patient has also had two urinary tract infections in the past two years. On review of systems, he has no acute weight changes, polyuria, vomiting, or diarrhea. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs. He does not take any medication or supplements. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient seems underdeveloped in stature and muscle mass. Muscle strength is grossly 4/5 in all four extremities. Fingerstick blood glucose is 160 mg/dL. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in his bloodwork results?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of childhood growth restriction, recurrent kidney stones, and prior urinary tract infections presents for evaluation of weakness. Together, this constellation of symptoms is suspicious for renal tubular acidosis (likely type 1), which would cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.

There are several causes of a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA), which is defined as an anion gap of 4-12. NAGMA frequently occurs with hyperchloremia in the setting of bicarbonate loss rather than extra acid production. Renal and gastrointestinal causes are the most common, but other causes exist, such as iatrogenic causes. Hyperalimentation from parenteral nutrition and excessive 0.9% saline infusions (“normal” saline is not physiologically “normal”) are common causes in the inpatient setting. Profuse diarrhea can lead to NAGMA via bicarbonate loss. Hypoaldosteronism and the use of spironolactone have also been implicated. Finally, renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a commonly overlooked cause of NAGMA. Younger patients are more likely to have type 1 or type 2, whereas older patients or those with chronic medical issues may have type 4 renal tubular acidosis.
